subject: Leaving Ashford
event: And just in time! We've had a marvelous time here, but now the castle is being converted to Hogwart's and rapidly filling up with screaming children in Harry Potter costumes. Aieeee. Run away, run away, run far away...

comments.article:
*laughs*

You can't really run away fast enough I think... it's everywhere! Think it this way, at least it's not Twilight.. *laughs*
Yeah, at least these kids are fans of something worth reading - something that they will gain something from.
Could be worse.  Could be screaming adults in Harry Potter costumes.
I'm glad you had such a good time :) What is it with you and Harry Potter though? :D Long live Hogwarts and King's Landing XD
GOBLET OF FIRE beat A STORM OF SWORDS to win the 2001 Hugo Award. I think GRRM is still haunted by it ;-)
LOL run for your life!
...uh oh. Lock up the broomsticks and Red Bull.
comments.subject: Sounds like a trap.

comments.article: LOL

But what if it was filling up with screaming children dressed in ASOIAF costumes? Then again, we'd probably learn that some parent had their kids dress as Cersei and Jaime.

...yeah, maybe not. @_@

But those are your future fans and readers...

I know, my son started reading Harry Potter back when she first started, and now (that he's 21) he's reading the Song of Ice and Fire series.
comments.subject: You may not like them now George

comments.article: I agree... I still am a Harry Potter fan, but I've moved on to more adult fantasy like ASOIAF now that I'm a bit older.
comments.subject: Re: You may not like them now George

comments.article: I always love reading your not a blog, but this is probably my most favourite entry so far :D

Oh man, don't get me going on adults in Harry Potter costumes. And when I say that, I mean me, since I have a Harry Potter robe that I use as bathrobe when I am feeling down. There's nothing quite like wearing a Harry Potter robe on a gray Sunday to make yourself feel better!

Have fun in Belfast, though! Send pictures!
Putting on my Harry Potter robe makes me about 1000x happier too.

Sounds like a con from hel. Like WC Fields, I like children - for breakfast. Though if they're polite children, I might offer to share...

Glad you had fun. You look good with a hawk on your hand.

:D Just you wait. You will probably generate hordes of cosplayers soon enough.

I actually adore them, but I can understand wanting to not be trampled by the crowd.
Harry Potter is to Song of Ice and Fire as McDonald's is to Morimoto.  But I confess, I occasionally crave a big mac.
dude, I agree with ya.
See... If you were a prolific writer it could have been filled with teenagers and adults and been converted to a red wedding.
I would very much love to see a "GRRM v. HP"

I'm not sure if this criticism of Rowling sits well with me. It is after all a children's series and nowhere near as complex a series as a Song of Ice and Fire. I understand that parrismcb is being supportive of GRRM, as we all are, but it seems rather... beneath GRRM's fandom to be taking potshots (no pun intended) at Harry Potter and Rowling.

Yes, they're kid's books, but they're also a wonderful read for young adults as a gateway to more complex fantasy (like Game of Thrones! :) ) and one of the things that always resonated with me was how genuine and relatable most of Rowling's scenes with children are. Both Rowling and George R. R. Martin really excel when it comes to writing realistic scenes with children... which is a rare thing in the sf/fantasy genre.
comments.subject: As a fan of both Harry Potter *and* ASoIaF...

comments.article:
Actually, I don't mind Harry Potter... although the last book sucked. THe ones that came before were enjoyable enough.

My friend Melinda Snodgrass had a much better ending for the HP seires than the one Rowling came up with. And I won't even get into the hundres of pages of Harry Goes Camping.

For kid's fantasy, I'd take HP over Narnia any day.
comments.subject: Re: As a fan of both Harry Potter *and* ASoIaF...
Re: As a fan of both Harry Potter *and* ASoIaF...

comments.article: Well, i doubt there are many parents out there that would let their children read ASOIAF...so George doesn't have to worry about lil kids running round in ASOIAF costumes...
Harry Potter is obviously for children, and many things in the books simply do not make sense, which is galling...
comments.subject: Harry Potter

comments.article:
Hi George...apropos of nothing, was curious if anyone has mentioned this to you?

Last night I was watching "Futurama" feature-length episode "Beast With a Billion Backs" with my kids, and as the plot unfolded, I began to wonder whether the screenplay was a sort of small homage to "A Song for Lya."

The plot revolves around a giant alien organism that offers eternal love and connection through physical union with all of humanity...

Money quotes:
"Stop resisting, my brethren! Don't you want to be part of something bigger than yourselves? Like a big crazy monster?"
"Why should you be satisfied with one man when love needs to share itself with the whole universe?"

I also noticed little details, such as how the creature in it insists on being called "shklee" which reminded me of your Shkeen.

I wonder if the guy who wrote it was a fan of yours and of your classic '70s short stories.

You can read the script here:
http://www.futurama-madhouse.com.ar/scripts/5acv07.shtml
Somewhat unrelated, but great ASOIF references in today's "Manly Guys Doing Manly Things" comic.  I guess the artist is a big fan.

you mentioned - got a link for that?
thx
comments.subject: couldn't find the site

comments.article: sorry to go off topic but are you going to do a write up to support the Mountain? It would be a dream come true to have you a Joe Abercrombie writing about the same match up.  If the mountain and the Feared came up against each other and you both do a right up millions of fans will get a huge thrill
comments.subject: suvudu is at it again

comments.article:
I think they're rather adorable. They had a Hogwart's academy at MileHi Con, and it was delightful. A chemistry professor was teaching "potions", they had a physicist. Another lady was slipping in Latin lessons under the guise of teaching them proper wand use and spell pronunciation. They were writing essays about observing Muggles at a science fiction convention. They were learning and didn't even know it.

Melinda

LOL!!! that is funny as hell, imagining you sir, running away from all the "Harry Potter" fans!!! I think sir, that you shall challenge JK Rowling to a writing duel, both of you sitting down facing each other, having one hour to penn a short story! And then the works to be judged, voted on and to choose a winner! Of course there is always a good old fashioned sword fight (or in this case sword vs. wand?!?!?). Before she can say "Avacadavra", well you can slay her..LOL!

Just kidding obviously, and though this may make you hate me, I am a fan of both of your works, and am thankful that I have the choice, possibility and freedom to read books as varied and different as those comprising the sagas of "A Song Of Ice And Fire" and "Harry Potter"!
comments.subject: Harry Potter VS. A Song Of Ice And Fire!!!!

comments.article:
"...the castle is being converted to Hogwart's and rapidly filling up with screaming children in Harry Potter cotsumes."

That sounds like a dream come true. :')

Rather than antagonist Ms. Rowling and Mr. Martin should be considered both door openers though very different doors. Many may pass through Ms. Rowling's door to discover Mr. Martin's and be glad to have found both portal's. Though its hard to pass through them in opposite order.

That Ms. Rowling's portal turns out to be "high school" level while Mr. Martin's a "university" level, hardly matters after all college does little good if you can't already read.

And speaking of reading, all of us with with school age children can attest that the ability to get kids to read before Harry Potter and after Potter can't be understated. Many an author yet unborn will reap the benefits of Ms. Rowling changing a whole culture's attitude toward reading.

As to costumes, I was once accosted by a Georgia Tech football fan while at the Dragon Con parade re my Star Wars costume. He had painted his face Gold/black and was wearing a yellow jacket shaped hat. He could not grasp the irony.

Irrational exuberance can be a good thing in life as not all want to live lives of quite desperation. Consumers and producers of fantasy literature should intuitively understand this.

TomT
comments.subject: Mr. Martin goes to Hogwarts
